2 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR r now Nebraska Has Wrought Wonders in Last Few Years It would require volume after volume to compile and publish all the facts regarding the productive wealth of Nebraska for the year 1915 To study the facts regarding Nebraska's resources and prosperitj become an enthusiast on the subject. Agriculturally, Nebraska has made wonderful progress in the last few yean. Nebraska stands second to no state in the United StaU tion to the acre. No other state can approach her record in the p< of development. No other state can equal her record of product capita for the year 1915. Nebraska owes it to herself and make known to the world the golden opportunities for th dustrious within her borders. There is need to cultivate the spirit of supporting More factories are needed to consume the raw material braska farms. Every article manufactured in Nebraska an produced in Nebraska should be the articles and products which N t Every dollar made in Nebraska and spent for Nebraska Nebraska produced products is a dollar kept in Nebraska t tantly growing total volume of business. Every dollar st braska made goods and Nebraska produced produc employers of Nebraska labor, and well employed labor community. Dollars sent out of the state very infrec r< Nebraska needs the same degree of assistance ir :ii development that has been accorded to its agricultural develop should be in the many hamlets and cities in the state local employment to labor, to use the raw material, and to build for every locality a larger home market. This is the important work for this stat V from this time on. Industrial development has not kept pace with the agricultural d opment. Citizens of Nebraska have every opportunity, and the results of industry are certain and sure. Nebraska has wrought wonders in the half century of her existence nearing a close.

4 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR The Selection and Care of Seed Corn By Envin Hopt Kt has been the general habit in this state to select seed corn either the crib or hastily from the field while shucking corn. There is no ng the fact that oftentimes this practice gives seed corn that grows l satisfactorily. As a jreneral proposition, however, both methods, and ially the first, is decidedly faulty. Some years either is disastrous. The weakness of crib selection are evident as soon as attention is calle< to them. Good looking rather than pood seed ears are chosen. In the cril one can tell nothing of the field conditions under which an ear grow. Th< chances are that it has been grown where the stand was thin, or in a low fertile, or otherwise favored spot. A fine appearing ear thus urown deserves no credit. The real test of the hereditary power or "blood lines" in a corn- i t: is: Will it produce ■ good ear under average field conditions? Under >nably severe competition and adversity, the inherently best corn makes ears. The weakest makes either poor ears or none at all. It would seem this that seed corn should never be picked from spots where con - ns are more favorable than the field as a whole. In west and central ■aska it is often very dry. There, resistance to drouth is badly needed irn. Rather poor looking seed ears picked from among still poorer ones If seasons are apt to be really much better seed than good looking ones •d in favorable years or from especially favored spots. Individual Ear Test Find or make a box about 30 inches square and 4 inches deep. A box of this size will allow space for 100 squares 2 l ,«> by 2U inches, and at the same time leave a vacant space 2M> inches wide around the edj?e of the box. KThe bottom of the terminator should not be made too tight, for o up it will swell and warp. A good plan is to leave crack.- ab< th of an inch wide between the boards to allow for expansion. ( these cracks on the inside with thin strips of wood nailed edge only, or cover with a cloth. The best medium for holding the water ncePssaiv is sawdust. If sawdust cannot be secured, sand or soil will do. Ab inches of wet sawdust should be put into the germinator and be sr and packed. K Prepare as follows, a sheet of white cloth about 30 inches square to be upon the sawdust: Mark upon this cloth 100 spaces. 2'j inches square squares each way). This leaves a margin of about 2'~j inches unused 11 sides. The squares should be numbered as shown in the germinator. I Wet the cloth and spread smoothly over the sawdust. Before kernels placed upon the squares there must be some way of telling from which the kernels on each square were taken. There are at least two simple s of doing this: First — A rack may be made of l-by-4-inch boards nailed ther and forming a square 25 inches across. Wires are stretched across both ways of 2*4 inches and firmly secured. Second — a still simpler way 3 cut heavy paper or cardboard into %-inch squares. These squares numbered from 1 to 100 and secured to the butts of the ears by means ins, tacks, or small nails. This system of numbering is especially advis - in schools or where many people are likely to handle the ears. Six kernels should be taken from each ear, two near the butt on op - posite sides of the ear, two from the middle, and two from near the tip. Remove the kernels with a knife blade by prying at their edges. Pulling in this manner will not injure the "germs." Place the six kernels on the

RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 5 proper square with the germ side up. The corn now on the squares should be protected by a second cloth about 30 inches square. This shield cloth should be firmly woven muslin, or the rootlets will grow thru it. Wet the •loth and lay it smoothly over the kernels. Take a large cloth (almost anything will do) and lay it over the germinator. and cover with an inch wet sawdust. Fold the edges over the sawdust. If the cloth is not small it will completely cover the top of the sawdust, making a sort pad or niattre The germinator should be kept in a living room or kitchen, where the not change greatly. A temperature varying from 70 to peratu 80 degrees is best. Under favorable conditions of temperature, a test should be completed in a week or less. Sometimes it is necessary to sprinkle water over the pad in order to keep it moist enough. The only way to be sure that corn will germinate is to try it and see. Lack of germinative power in corn usually results from unsoundness or lack of ripeness. M have the following qualities are usually unsound and r should be discarded without going to the expense of testing them in the germinator: 1. The ear is easily twisted, or the kernels are loose on the cob. 2. The kernels are dull, dark, or otherwise discolored. The hulls of the kernels are badly blistered. 4. The germ is dark yellow or otherwise discolored. A Method of Testing A simple general test will tell whether it will be necessary to go to the expense of testing every seed ear planted. Such a test may be made by selecting 100 ears from seed corn in such a manner as to make sure that the ears selected are representative. Remove one kernel from near the middle of each ear selected. Place the 100 kernels in a pie tin or dinner plate germinator. Set aside in a warm place. It will be necessary to watch moisture con - ditions from day to day. As kernels sprout, remove them from the germi - nator. This will lessen the possibility of molds interfering with the test. At the close of six days call the test complete and find the per cent of germi - nation. If 90 per cent or more of the kernels have sprouted, it will probably not pay to make a test of each ear. Should less than 90 per cent germinate, t will probably pay to make an individual ear test. In preparing to inspect the test it is best to roll carefully to one side first the sawdust pad and then the shield cloth, instead of merely pulling them off. If kernels stick to the shield cloth as it is rolled off, brush them back into their proper squares. Ordinarily no ear should be saved for seed unless all six of its kernels germinate.

6 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR Facts About the State of Nebraska Admitted to statehood March, 1867. Area, 77,000 square miles. Acres, 49,200,000. Population, 1910, 1,200,000. Third largest wheat producer. Third largest oats producer. Fourth largest corn producer. Second largest alfalfa producer. Has third largest stock in the world. Has largest single creamery in the world. Omaha is the largest butter market in the world. Has the largest river within the borders of a single state. Fifth largest butter producing state. Nebraska's egg crop in 1914 was worth more than all the gold anc silver mined in Colorado and California in the same year. Nebraska's small grain crop in 1915 is worth more than all the world's production of tobacco and copper. The products of Nebraska soil for a single year would fill a freight train 12,000 miles long. Newport, Rock County, Nebraska, is the largest hay shipping rail - road station in the world. The second largest smelter of fine ores in the world is at Omaha The counties of Richardson, Johnson, Otoe, Cass and Nemaha, Ne - braska, produce more apples every year than the states of Wash - ington, Oregon and Idaho. Packed in pound cartons and the cartons stacked on end, the butter output of Nebraska in a single year would make a column of butter 2,300 miles high. Scottsbluff, in the extreme west end of Nebraska, is the largest single railroad shipping point in the United States. Nebraska's agricultural and live stock production in 1915 is worth more than the nation's output of coal during the same year. Nebraska spends more per capita for education than any other state and has the largest per capita permanent school fund. In 1914 Nebraska's manufacturing plants turned out products worth $161,922,974.38. Nebraska's grand total of production in 1914, agricultural, live stock, dairy, fruit and manufactured products totalled, approximately, more than $700,000,000.

RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 7 Nebraska's Progress is Being Recognized H. M. Bushnell, recognized as one of the best posted and foremost writers in the state on matters pertaining to the resources of the state, wrote the following for the January (1916) issue of the Lincoln Trade Re- view "Never before in the history of this commonwealth has it been accorded such recognition over the entire United States as it is receiving at the pres- me. In the last two years, when there was such depressing conditions a. large extent of the country reaching up to a few months ago, Ne- braska was an example of unmixed prosperity that caused it to stand out in the most marked way in the view of all those who see and observe business ons and progress 'Slow, indeed, has been the coming from the eastern section of the try, of the recognition that Nebraska has been entitled to, not only in the last year, but for a number of years. The provincialism of that section has been shown in this, as in other ways, but the wall of prejudice and in- what Nebraska is, has been leveled so that today there is state on the Atlantic coast and few people in that section but that are cing about Nebraska and its wonderful record of prosperity. The cities of Nebraska are recipient, too, in the general larger under - ing of this state and its advancement. For a year, Omaha and Lincoln have been pointed to by those who travel from state to state as the two most prosperous cities in the country. There is a pleasure and a satisfaction in the coining of such just recognition of this state. The influence of this state and its opportunities will be inquired into more and more; business in every line seeking a new territory and larger field will turn and center its attention in this direction, while capital will be more and more interested in making investment in a land and locality where such an unbroken record of con - tinued prosperity opens before it. "We have, in the past years, had much for which to be thankful and much over which to congratulate ourselves, but never before have we had the universal recognition that now comes to this state."

8 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR Toted Population, Increase and Distribution The population of the state of Nebraska, according to the census of 1910, is 1,192,214. Compared with a population of 1,066,300 in 1900, this represents an increase during the last decade of 125,914, or 11.8 per cent. During the same period the total population of the United States increased 21 per cent. The rate of increase for the population of the state during the preceding decade, 1890-1900, was only three-tenths of one per cent. The following table shows the population of Nebraska at each census from 1860 to 1910, inclusive, together with the increase and per cent of in - crease during each decade, in comparison with the per cent of increase for the United States as a whole. (Nebraska was organized as a territory in 1854 and was enumerated rately for the first time at the census of 1860. During the 30 years i 1860 to 1890 the growth of Nebraska was very rapid. The population he state increased more than fourfold during the decade 1860-1870, it three and two-thirds times during the decade 1870-1880, and a little ; than two and one-third times during the decade 1880-1890. The abso - increase for this 30 year period was 1,033,815. During the 20 years > 1890 the population of the state, according to the census, has increased 558, or only 12.2 per cent During every decade from 1860 to 1890 the rates of increase for the state were very much higher than the rates of increase for the United States, the population of the state being more than thirty-six times as great in 1890 as it was in 1860, while that of the United States had about doubled. Since 1890, however, the population of the United States has increased much more rapidly than that of Nebraska, the rate of increase for the country as a whole during this period being 46.1 per cent, as against 12.2 per cent for the state. Nebraska has ninety-three counties. The population of these counties range from 260 in Arthur county to 168.546 in Douglas county. The total land area in the state is 76,808 square miles. RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 9 number of persons to the square mile in 1910 was 15.5; in 1900 and 1890 it was 13.9 and 13.8, respectively. The average number per square mile for the United States as a whole was 30.9. Cherry county, with 5,979 square miles, has the largest area, and Sarpy county, with 240 square miles, has the smallest area. Douglas county, con - taining Omaha city, has the highest density of any county, namely 509J2 persons per square mile, and Arthur county, with 1.4 persons per square le, has the lowest density. The urban territory of the state in 1910 — that is, the cities and incor - porated villages of 2,500 inhabitants or more — contained 310,852 inhabitants, or 26.1 per cent of the total population, while 881,362 inhabitants, or 73J per cent, lived in rural territory. The urban territory as it existed in 1900 — that is. the cities having 2,500 inhabitants or more— contained 252,702 in - habitants, or 23.7 per cent of the total population, while 813,598 inhabitants. >r 76.3 per cent, lived in rural territory. There has thus been a slight in - crease in the proportion of urban population. During the decade 1890-1900 here was an apparent decrease in the proportion of urban population in the itate. but this may have been due to an overcount of the population of cer - ain cities in 1890. For the United States as a whole the urban population constituted 46.3 per cent of the total population in 1910 and 40.5 per cent of he total population in 1900. 10 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR Farm and Farm Property of the State I The state of Nebraska, which ranks fifteenth in land area and twenty-ninth opulation among the states and territories of continental United States, entirely within the Great Plains region. The surface slopes gently east - i from an altitude of approximately 5,000 feet in the extreme western ion of the state to an altitude of 1,000 feet along the Missouri River, ■h bounds it on the east. The eastern portion of the state is rolling and ?what dissected by the major stream drainages. The central and west - portions consist of undulating to rolling upland prairies crossed by the d shallow valleys of the principal streams. KThe eastern portion of Nebraska, constituting a broad belt nearly par - with the Missouri River, lies within the glaciated portion of the Great is, and the soils are derived principally from a silty layer of the loess h overlies the glacial till. The prevailing soil of the upland prairies of I section is a dark brown silty loam. Immediately to the west of this on are level to rolling prairies which constitute practically all the south ral portion of the state, and which are occupied by a broad expanse of loess which overlies the consolidated rocks and gives rise to brown and >w silty loam soils. The north central portion of the state, north of the te River, is occupied by an extensive tract of sand hills interspersed i small, level, sandy prairies. Within this region grazing is the dominant i of agricultural occupation, although many of the more level tract.-; arp coming to be occupied for the purpose of dry farming. Practically all of the northern bonier of Nebraska constitu of the northern residual prairies, whose soils are prevailingly heavy loams and clay loams suited to grazing and to dry farming. »The extreme western portion of the state consists of rolling pied by loams and sandy loams which support the wild grasses te chiefly a grazing area. The rainfall over the whole state is sufficient for growing grain crops without irrigation, the normal annual precipitation ranging from II inches at the western boundary to 30 inches at the eastern boundary. In the ex - treme western part of the state, however, irrigation is practiced to a consid - erable extent. >Of the state's entire land area, nearly four-fifths is in farms. The pro - ion varies considerably in the different counties, and ranges from 36.1 cent in McPherson county to 98.7 per cent in Cass county. In the ities in the eastern half of the state, with few exceptions, more than 80 cent of the land is in farms, while in nearly all the counties in the west - half the percentage is below 80. Nebraska's Farms and Farm Acreage The following statistics, taken from the 1910 census, present, for the state as a whole for each census from 1860 to 1910, inclusive, a statement of the total population, the number of farms, and the acreage of farm land and of improved land in farms. They also give the percentage of the land area in farms, the percentage of farm land improved, and the percentage of increase during each decade in the number of farms and in the land in farms.

12 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR FARMS LANDS IN FARM ALL LA Mi Iln the fifty years since 1860 the population of Nebraska has increased i 28,841 to 1,192,214, or about fortyfold. By far the greater part of the •ase in population occurred between 1860 and 1890. KFrom 1900 to 1910 an increase of 8,153, or 6.7 per cent, took place in number of farms. For the decade between 1890 and 1900 the increase 7,917, or 7 per cent. From I860, when the number of farms was small, increase was rapid until 1890, since which time it has been comparatively The land area of Nebraska is approximately 49,157,120 acres, of which 38,622,021 acres, or 78.6 per cent, are included in farms. Of this farm acreage, 24,382,577 acres, or 63.1 per cent, are reported as improved land, representing 49.6 per cent of the total land area of the state. The total acreage of farm land increased 29.1 per cent during the last decade, while the acreage of improved land show? an increase of 32.3 per jr same period. From 1870 to 1910 the increase in total farm acr improved acreage was rapid and fairly uniform. The percent: land improved increased rapidly from 1860 to 1890. reaching - latter year, then fell to 61.6 in 1900, a proportion somewhat that reported in 1910. The only county in which more than one-half the farms were 1909 was Seottsbluff. where the percentage was 62.2. In five other counties the proportion was between 10 and 20 per cent and in five it was 5 per cent or over but less than 10 per cent. From 1899 to 1909 the number of farms on which irrigation was prac- I decreased 4.1 per cent in the state as a whole. Only three of the counties for which comparative figures are available show increases in the number of such farms, but in two of these the increases were large — 368 x and 141.2 per cent in Seottsbluff. Both of these counties ire affected by the North Platte project of the United State Reclamation >ttsbluff county contains land supplied by another large en- terprise. The decrease in the state outside of the three counties mentioned was due to a succession of wet seasons and the increase in the practice of Iry farming. The total acreage reported as irrigated in 1909 was 255,950, as against I4MM in 1899 and 11,744 in 1889. The increase from 1889 to 1899 was 136,794 acres, or 1,164.8 per cent, while from 1899 to 1909 it was 107,412 acres, or 72.3 per cent. The fact that there was an increase between 1899 and 1909 in the acreage irrigated by a decrease in the number of farms irrigated is ex - plaind by the abandonment of irrigation in parts of the state where it wu practiced on a small scale and its extension in the western counties where the rainfall is less and where much larger parts of the farms are irrigated. humls in fnrnis— acres - 38,<E>,ftn 29.9U.TO Nun i her of farms irrigated — — — - 1.SS2 1.932

14 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR KScottsbluff county, with an irrigated area of 100,301 acres in 1909 and 14 acres in 1899, had the largest acreage of irrigated land at both cen- B, while Iincoln county, with 34,760 acres in 1909 and 22,508 acres in , had the next largest acreage under irrigation in both years. »The irrigated land in Scottsbluff county in 1909 formed 21.7 per cent s total land area. In Morrill county, which shows the next highest pro - ion, irrigated land represented only 3.2 per cent of the total area. The table shows that in 1910 existing enterprises were ready to supply water to 429,225 acres, or 173,475 acres more than were irrigated in 1909. The difference is considerably greater than the amount of land brought under irrrigation in the 10 years from 1899 to 1909. The acreage included in projects exceeds the acreage irrigated in 1909 by 424,183 acres, which is almost four times the acreage brought under irrigation in the last decade and more than one and one-half the acreage irrigated in 1909. This acreage represents the area which will be available for the extension of irrigation within the next few years upon the completion of the projects now under construction and without new undertakings. 16 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR There are 3,468.28 unclassified acres in the several counties of the state. Lancaster county contains 2,308.46 acres of unclassified saline lands. I The Commissioner of Public Lands and Buildings may at least once in i year designate a day and hour for offering in a public manner, at the e of the county treasurer in the respective counties, lease contracts on all he educational lands, which may be subject to lease in that county at time of such offering. The same shall be subject to lease at an annual al of six (6) per cent on the appraised value. Provided, that if two or e parties desire to lease the same land, the officer having the control of auction shall lease to the person who will pay the greater amount of i bonus in addition to six i6> per cent on the appraised value as annual al. t Lease rentals are due in two installments. January 1 and July 1 of each If not paid within six months after due, the lease holders are de - •d delinquent and notice is sent th«m if their postoffice addresses are m; if unknown, advertisement is made in a newspaper. Ninety days • date of such notice lease contracts are declared forfeited and are sub - to auction thereafter. K Delinquent lease holders are not permitted to bid at the sale of the 5 they have forfeited, but at any time before the land is actually put he auction block they may reinstate their leases by paying all back ils and penalty fees. KA11 school lands under lease are subject to appraisement every s, if the Board of Educational Lands and Funds so elects. Any lessee of land situated within the area irrigated or to be irrigated from irrigation works constructed or controlled for to be constructed or controlled by the United States or its duly authorized agencies) or any lessee of any 40-acre tract or government subdivision, any part of which is under irrigation may purchase the same. Nebraska's Dairy Industry Growing Rapidly Figures compiled by the Pure Food Department of the state show that 41,776,080 pounds were produced in the creameries of the state for the year 1913-14. These figures are estimated to be about 5,000,000 short of the pro - duction for the year 1914-15, as the butter made is estimated to be that much greater for the latter period. PNot only is the state producing the amount of butter as listed in the s herewith given, but it is also supplying much cream for factories at ,-er, Boulder, Concordia, St. Joseph, Council Bluffs and Sioux City, all ide the state. When the amount sent to these places is added to that of own Nebraska creameries it will give about 10,000,000 pounds more.

Fred Schneider Norfolk 100 West Point 100,00( Cedar Valley Creamery Co. .Spalding 100.00C Total pounds manufactured 41.7 Alfalfa Acreage Being Steadily Developed ■ The total estimated acreage of alfalfa in Nebraska in 191 acres. The acreage in 1914 was 1,022,485; in 191" the 978.865. Twenty years ago, the acreage was small but not to I a ted, in the crop report. Every county in the state produces alfalfa; even in the thinly settled sand hill counties there is rapidly being developed a good alfalfa acreage. From the 1,191,310 acres in alfalfa in 1915, an estimated crop of 4,088,598 tons was produced. Estimating this tonnage at $6.00 per ton, the alfalfa crop in 1915 is placed at $24,531,588. The value of the alfalfa crop in 1914 was estimated by the same authority at $22,46fi,385. The average production of tons per acre of alfalfa in 1915 was 3.42. The average produc - tion in 1914 was 3.13 tons per acre. Polk county that produced 56,764 tons last year, is given the record yield per acre among all the counties, the esti - mated yield per acre in that county being 4.3 tons. The five counties in

RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 19 Nebraska leading in the production of alfalfa in 1915 in their order, were as follows: Buffalo 153,612 tons Boone 140,090 tons 129,467 tons Bluff 116,610 tons The five counties leading in the production of alfalfa in 1914 were the same, but their order in volume of production is entirely changed. In 1914, Custer was the first county in alfalfa production and Scotts Bluff second, while in 191."), these two counties are in fourth and fifth place. Dawson that was in fourth place in 1914, heads the list in 1915. The value of the alfalfa crop of Nebraska is probably in dollars and cents, estimated lower than any other field crop. So much of it is fed on the farm that only occasionally a good estimate is secured through selling the crop from a certain acreage of what the yield per acre is. As one of Nebraska's big crops, alfalfa is tly reaching upward to a higher position. Natural Wild Hay Production and Valuation <o little tame hay is grown in Nebraska outside of clover and timothy, almost entirely for pasturage, that the hay crop of Nebraska is to all and purposes, a crop of nautral wild hay. Tabulations for 1915 give the number of acres used for hay at 2,635,463. The acreage of hay in 1914 The yield of wild hay in Nebraska in 1915 was 1.18 tons per acre and the production in tons was 3,132,219. This is an increased production in tonnage of hay in Nebraska over 1914 when the record gave the production at 2,202,357 tons. The state board of agriculture estimates the price of wild hay at $6.00 per ton and at this valuation the hay crop of 1915 was worth $l.v7!t:! n4. The five counties leading in the production of wild hay in 1915, The five leading counties in hay production in 1914 in their order were: Cherry, Holt, Lincoln, Custer and Brown. Sioux and Rock counties in 1915 replace Lincoln and Brown counties in the five counties of largest production. Cherry county, the largest county in the state, with its great acreage of uncultivated lands, stands far to the front of all hay producing counties in the state. Sioux county, the northwest county of Nebraska for the first time Dawson 154,971 tons leir order are as 1 follows : o Cherry 372,025 tons Holt Custer Sioux Rock 173,422 tons 165,728 tons 109,869 tons 93,957 tons

Rock county in the list of t counties for 1915, is one of the greatest hay shipping counties in the Corn Acreage of State Widely Distributed The largest volume of bushels of corn that has been produced in Nebraska for eight years is the estimate for the 1915 crop. The market value of the 1915 crop is said to be the largest in dollars and cents of any crop ever sent to market. The corn crop of Nebraska for 1915 was produced from 6,991 i.o:;i acres. The corn crop of 1914 was grown upon 6,530,078 acres. The average yield of corn for 1915 is 32.5 bushels per acre. This is the largest yield recorded for the last eight years. In 1914 the average yield m J.~> ami fraction bushels to the acre. Corn production in 1914 was much larger than it was in 1913. With the crop of 1915, 20 per cent greater than that of the year previous, the returns, with the high prices prevailing that far securing for their corn crop, are in volume surprisingly large: Not years has the average production of the state been so widely distributed. 1 five leading corn producing counties in Nebraska in 1915, in the as follows: Custer 5,94h,451 bush Saunders 5,820,3.">0 bus! Lancaster 5,734,395 bust Knox 5,456,10:: bush Gage 5,406.277 bush The five counties leading in corn production in 1914 in W( Custer, Saunders, Platte, Knox and Lancaster. In the list there is only one change in the five leading counties in 1915, P out from the five of 1914 and Gage taking its place in the list of 1915. Custer and Saunders still retain first and second place unchanged. Lar -l advanced from fifth place to third place; Knox county remains in fourth p and Gage county is in fifth place. In the corn producing counties ir in the list of those producing over a million bushels, the five counties showing I largest acreage yield per acre for 1915 were Washington, 4fi bushels; lilton county, 45 bushels; Sarpy, 44 bushels; Wayne, 43 bushels; Richard - 42 bushels. There were ten counties in the state having an average yield irer 40 bushels to the acre. In 1914 the five counties showing the highest I per acre in their order, were: Greeley, Douglas, Burt. Nemaha and hington. Washington is the only county that has retained its place in the leading counties in yield and it has also grown from the last place in the af 1914 to first place in the list of 1915. Custer county, while leading in the total production of corn in the list of counties, shows an average yield per acre of 24% bushels.

RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 21 Winter Wheat Crop Largest in State's History The production of winter wheat for the year 1914 was the largest ever produced, but the 1915 production exceeded that of 1914. Thus 1915 is the banner year in the production of winter wheat in the history of Nebraska. The estimate of the 1915 crop of winter wheat is 67,158,641 bushels. At a valuation of 80 cents per bushel, this makes the winter wheat crop of the state worth $57,016,174. The winter wheat crop in 1915 was produced from 399,331 acres, and the average yield per acre was 19.7 bushels. The govern- ment estimate for the winter wheat crop in Nebraska in 1915 was 73,712,000 bushels. The 1914 winter wheat crop was 63,755,515 bushels. The total acre - age for winter wheat in 1914 was 3,373,935. In yield per acre, the estimate of 19.7 bushels for 1915 is practically a bushel higher than for the preceding year. The five counties in Nebraska leading in winter wheat production in 1915, with the number of bushels produced in each county, are as follows: Hamilton 3,169,005 York 2,822,848 Lancaster 2,454,410 The largest production of winter wheat was in the center of the South :e inter wheat belt. The five leading counties in winter wheat production in their order in 1914 were Clay, Adams, Fillmore, Hamilton and Lancaster. A number of other counties were close competitors for position in the five iding counties, only a small shortage in yield occurring in them when upared with the five listed. In the counties producing over a million bushels of winter wheat in 1915 the five counties having the largest average yield per acre, were York, with a yield of 28.2 bushels to the acre; Saunders, 24.1; Lancaster, 23.9; Butler, 23.7, and Cass, 23.5. Saline 62,449,591 Clay 2,313,171

22 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR Nebraska's Spring Wheat Acreage The northwestern part of the state is the spring: wheat section of Ne - braska. There were grown in Nebraska in 1915 224,265 acres of spring wheat. The average production was 18.2 bushels, and the production in Kiels 4,110,327. In 1914 the production was 3,973,537 bushels. The yield 1915 is 18.2 bushels. In 1914 it was 12 bushels to the acre. The five ing* counties in spring: wheat production for 1915, with the bushels pro - d in each, were as follows: Cheyenne 808,812 bushel Sheridan 259,785 bushel Chase .210,383 bushel Banner 195,020 bushel Dawes 14932 bushel I All these leading counties in spring wheat production are in western -aska. The five leading counties in spring wheat production in 1914 were, eir order, Cheyenne, Knox, Chase, Dawes and Frontier. Cheyenne, Chase, Dawes remain in the leading counties for 1915. In high yields in 1915 Butte county leads with an average of 25.5 bushels to the acre; Cheyenne an average of 24.2; Dawes, 23.8; Morrill, 22.5; and Scotts Bluff, 21.5. Rye Crop Largely Increased in 1915 I The 1915 rye crop is estimated to be nearly a million bushels larger than of the 1914 crop. The total crop of rye in 1915 in Nebraska was 3,451, - bushels; this was produced from 210.690 acres, and the average yield per was 16.4 bushels. In 1914 Nebraska produced 2,790,760 bushels of rye from 175,459 acres, and the average yield that year was 16 bushels to the acre. The five leading counties in rye production in their order are : Custer 260.469 bushel Holt .243,000 bushel Blaine 218,925 bushel Lincoln 212,996 bushel Antelope 176,168 bushel The five leading counties in the production of rye remain the same as in 1914 with the exception that Lincoln county takes the place of Dawson county in the list.

RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 23 Potato Yield Estimated at 10,460,610 Bushels The Nebraska potato crop is estimated at 10,460,610 bushels for the year 1915. The 1915 crop was grown upon 97,284 acres and the average yield was lOT'o bushels to the acre. The potato crop of 1914 in Nebraska was grown on 83,807 acres. The five counties in Nebraska leading in potato production in 1915 follow: Cherry 1,015,393 bushels The five counties leading in potato production in 1914 were Box Butte, Scotts Bluff, Cherry, Hall and Brown in their order. Scotts Bluff and Hall counties dropped out of the five leading counties in potato production in 1915, Sheridan and Custer taking their places Box Butte county that was in first place in 1914, drops back to second place in 1915. Cherry, Box Butte, Sheri - dan and Brown counties are all in the great potato belt of northern Nebraska. This is one of the greatest potato sections of the United States and it is steadily expanding in its volume of production year by year. Apple Production for the Year 1915 in Nebraska The federal census bureau estimates the apple production for the year Nebraska at 1,270,000 bushels. This estimate is more than double the production for the year 1914. The state horticultural department esti - mates the 1915 production at a million and a half bushels. The five counties in the state leading in the number of bushels produced, according to the state horticultural department, follow: Nemaha 202,437 bushels 190,437 bushels 154,181 bushels 108,699 bushels . 69,115 bushels Richardson Washington Cass Otoe The southeastern counties of the state lead in apple production. Nemaha, according to estimates, produced the largest number of bushels of apples in both 1914 and 1915. Sox Butte.. Sheridan ... 24 STATE DEPARTMENT OF LABOR Nebraska's Largest Industry is That of Live Stock South Omaha is the second largest live stock market in the world in point of total receipts and the third largest packing center. It is the great market to which men come in search of feeder cattle and sheep, and while other markets, considerably older, have remained almost at a standstill so far as growth is concerned, the South Omaha market has shown a steady growth from year to year. tThe volume of business transacted by both the stock yards and the pack - houses of South Omaha exceeds a quarter of a billion dollars a year. The istics of the stock yards for the thirty-one years are of absorbing interest, ing that time 118,854,774 head of live stock, valued at approximately "6,000,000 were received at the yards. These receipts were divided as Sixty per cent of the live stock receipts at South Omaha originate in Nebraska, the balance coming from Colorado, Nevada, Iowa, Oregon. Idaho, South Dakota, Montana, Utah, Missouri and Wyoming. The live stock raisers of Nebraska received upwards of $60,000,000 for animals marketed at South Omaha during 1914. There are ten packing plants located at South Omaha because of the stock yards, and these plants, together with the stock yards, represent a total investment of $25,000,000, employ an average of 6,000 people and pay in wages approximately $6,000,000 a year. The pack - ing industry represents more than half of the total manufactures of Nebraska and exceeds the total gold production of the United States and Alaska by more than $20,000,000. battle Number 24,115,353 Value $1,358,000,000 losrs 55,514,833 1,110,000,000 Iheep lorses and Mules. 38,498,288 735,300 135,000,000 73,000,000 'otal 118,854,774 $2,676,000,000

RESOURCES OF NEBRASKA 51 Surplus Shipments Bulletins are issued each year by the State Department of Labor showing the surplus shipments of the various railway and express stations in the The figures herein given as to surplus shipments are tabulated and ed by the agents of express and railway companies at each forwarding n in the state. Errors may occur in the tabulation such as are common rembling a large number of figures with the use of adding machines. But taken as a whole the figures given are as accurate as statistics may be when assembled under inadequate rules and crude methods such as the Ne- w tatutes provide. To a limited degree the totals are affected by reshipments, the sum and I of the reshipments being an unknown quantity and impossible to rate from actual surplus shipments from a given forwarding point. Reshipments so long as they remain intrastate shipments would not rep- 'esent surplus shipments so far as the surplus production of the state is :oncerned, but would, if shipped from one county to another, affect surplus jnty from which the intrastate reshipment was for- warder urplus shipments represent production over and above that which is ed for local use and consumption; or, in other words, that which is shipped from the point of production to the point of use and consumption. The following tables show the surplus shipments of the various produc- he farm by counties for the year 1914:
